sections.text:
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
A comprehensive understanding of the relationships between the physicochemical properties and the behavior of nanomaterials in biological systems is required for designing safe and functional nanomaterials. Quantitative Structure-Activity Relationship (QSAR) methods help to establish such relationships, and their growing importance for providing key information is reflected in a number of regulatory frameworks (e.g., Registration Evaluation Authorization and Restriction of Chemical Substances (REACH)), where these approaches are considered acceptable, under certain conditions, for filling in knowledge gaps for untested chemicals. The (Q)SAR methodology is well known and extensively applied in the areas of drug discovery and chemical toxicity modeling for guiding the experimental design of chemical compounds, but its application to nanomaterials still requires major advancements. This review analyses the currently available (Q)S R models for regulatory assessment of nanomaterials risks. The survey first analyzes and discusses the regulatory relevance and reliability of models within the context of the 5 OECD (Q)SAR validation criteria. Then, the information required to apply the models is outlined, focusing especially on descriptor development. The most important mechanisms of toxicity, knowledge gaps that impede the development of structure-activity models, as well as the domains where (Q)SAR models are expected to convey fundamental contributions, such as in tiered testing schemes and analysis of functional assays’ results, are also discussed. It is concluded that the development of (Q)SAR models for nanomaterials requires both the development of nanospecific descriptors and curated experimental datasets.
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
A comprehensive assessment of the toxicological effects of nanomaterials is necessary for meeting regulatory requirements and for the design of products that are safe and operate as intended (Burello 2015). However, toxicological tests are time-consuming and resource intensive, which is why researchers are developing computational models to predict the behaviour and effects of nanomaterials in biological systems. Such predictions would allow researchers to streamline and prioritize toxicological tests, thus allowing a focus on the most promising (i.e., safer) nanomaterials.
Today, computational chemistry methods such as (Q)SARs ((Quantitative) Structure-Activity Relationships) are extensively applied in the area of toxicology and drug design to predict the physicochemical properties of chemicals and their effects in the human organism and in the environment. In the field of toxicology, (Q)SAR methods are typically applied towards the more elusive goal of predicting potential toxicity outcomes for in vitro cell cultures or in vivo animal test systems, where the toxicity endpoint (e.g., mutagenicity, developmental toxicity, cancer) tends to be less well understood, and is likely to encompass multiple mechanisms and pathways to adverse outcome, i.e., where no single interaction mechanism is known or anticipated (Cherkasov et al. 2014). For conventional chemicals, it is generally accepted that (Q)SAR success in modelling toxicity is more likely when one or more of the following conditions are met: (i) compounds within the training set are structurally similar (i.e., congeneric); (ii) the toxicity endpoint being modelled is either non-target specific or subject to relatively well-understood chemical reactivity principles; (iii) the toxicity endpoint is linked to a well-defined molecular target; or (iv) toxicity data are available for a sufficiently large number of diverse chemicals to capture all or most of the possible structure-activity associations, representing multiple possible adverse outcome pathways (AOP) within the same dataset (Cherkasov et al. 2014). Hence, a defining challenge for (Q)SAR applied to toxicology is that of balancing the highest possible endpoint resolution with the need for sufficient statistical representation.
An area of active (Q)SAR expansion is in the use of predictive models for regulatory purposes by government agencies, where a growing number of specialized regulatory tools and databases are being developed and validated (U.S. EPA 2015, JRC 2010). The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has expressed interest in several SAR approaches for food contact chemicals; they include DEREK, MultiCASE, and OncoLogic (FDA 2015). The REACH (Registration, Evaluation, Authorisation and Restriction of Chemicals) regulation, in Annex XI, par. 1.3, lists the following conditions for application of (Q)SARs instead of experimental testing (EU 2006): (i) “Results are derived from a (Q)SAR model whose scientific validity has been established; (ii) the substance falls within the applicability domain of the (Q)SAR model; (iii) results are adequate for the purpose of classification and labelling and/or risk assessment, and (iii) adequate and reliable documentation of the applied method is provided.” In its Guidance Document on the Validation of (Q)SAR models, the OECD provided a toolbox with five principles that validated (Q)SARs for chemicals should fulfil (OECD 2007). To facilitate its consideration for regulatory purposes, a (Q)SAR model should be associated with a defined endpoint, an unambiguous algorithm, a defined domain of applicability, appropriate measures of goodness-of-fit, robustness and predictivity, and a mechanistic interpretation.
In contrast to conventional chemicals, where it is possible to develop and validate computational models and methods by comparison with an adequate number of experimental studies, reliable effects and hazard data sets for nanomaterials which support in silico approaches are still limited. It has been more challenging to quantitatively relate physicochemical parameters/descriptors to given biological effects and fate characteristics of
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
nanomaterials due to a lack of reliable and relevant data that correlate mode-of-action (MOA) or AOP mechanisms for nanomaterials to categories of particles. Possible mechanisms for adverse health or ecological effects of nanomaterials include the following (Klaine et al. 2008, Nel 2006): oxidative stress/formation of reactive oxygen species, inflammation, protein denaturation/oxidation, membrane damage, DNA damage, interruption of energy transduction, immunity, granuloma formation, mitochondrial damage and release of toxic constituents. Some (Q)SAR models for metal oxides, based on particle’s reactivity and/or solubility may hold promise, but the field is still growing and requires more robust advancements to overcome knowledge gaps and lack of data. In this sense, computational methods may help focus in vivo and in vitro hazard and fate testing in a tiered testing and assessment schemes, or may help to analyse and predict the outcome of functional assays, which are designed to indicate certain modes of action or extrinsic properties of nanomaterials.
Since most of the current research addresses effects endpoints, rather than environmental or in vivo fate of nanomaterials (biokinetics), the focus at this time is on the review of research related to effect endpoints. However, the utility of fate descriptors (for traditional chemicals see for example ECOSAR, U.S. EPA 2015), such as solid-water partition coefficients, stickiness coefficients, and rate constants for dissolution, cannot be discounted and may help to develop reliable environmental fate models (Westerhoff and Nowack 2013). The objective of this review is to highlight the most relevant and reliable achievements in (Q)SAR modelling of nanomaterials in view of their application for regulatory purposes. The survey also discusses the most important knowledge gaps that impede the development of structureactivity models, outlining the domains where (Q)SAR models are expected to convey fundamental contributions, such as in tiered testing schemes and analysis of functional assays’ results.

sections.heading: 2. Compliance of the Examined Models with the 5 OECD Principles on (Q)SAR Validation
sections.text:
For validating (Q)SAR models for their use in regulatory assessment of chemical safety, the OECD member countries agreed on 5 principles (OECD 2007). The intent of Principle 1 (defined endpoint) is to ensure clarity in the endpoint being predicted by a given model, since a given endpoint could be determined by different experimental protocols and under different experimental conditions. It is therefore important to identify the experimental system that is being modelled by the (Q)SAR. The intent of Principle 2 (unambiguous algorithm) is to ensure transparency in the model algorithm that generates predictions of an endpoint from information on chemical structure and/or physicochemical properties. It is recognized that, in the case of commercially-developed models, this information is not always made publicly available. However, without this information, the performance of a model cannot be independently established, which is likely to represent a barrier for regulatory acceptance. The need to define an applicability domain (Principle 3) expresses the fact that (Q)SARs are reductionist models which are inevitably associated with limitations in terms of the types of chemical structures, physicochemical properties and mechanisms of action for which the models can generate reliable predictions. The Principle 4 (appropriate measures of goodness-of–fit, robustness and predictivity) indicates the need for assessing the internal performance of a model (as represented by goodness-of-fit and robustness) and the predictivity of a model (as determined by external validation). Finally, it is recognised that it is not always possible, from a scientific viewpoint, to provide a mechanistic interpretation of a given (Q)SAR (Principle 5), or that there might even exist multiple mechanistic interpretations of a given model. The absence of a mechanistic interpretation for a model does not mean that a model is not potentially useful in the regulatory context. The intent of Principle 5 is not
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
to reject models that have no apparent mechanistic basis, but to ensure that some consideration is given to the possibility of a mechanistic association between the descriptors used in a model and the endpoint being predicted, and to ensure that this association is documented.
The (Q)SAR models analysed in this report are summarized in table 1, which details whether each model complies with the 5 principles and describes briefly the information for each study. These principles are discussed in the following text (a similar work has been published recently by Oksel et al. (2017)).

AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
2.1 Defined endpoint
Some studies analysed in this report focus on the development of (Q)SAR models for human toxicity, others are based on ecotoxicity data - although E. coli is a faecal bacterium and not an organism which plays a role for determining ecotoxicity (see table 1). While only one study focusses on in vivo endpoints (Burello 2017), the rest of the literature concentrates on in vitro effects.
All studies considered are based on defined endpoints: this means that relevant information on how the toxicological tests are performed is described in detail (or references to original work are cited). It is therefore possible to replicate the experimental measurements reported in these studies and/or complement the datasets of tested samples with additional nanomaterials (tested under similar experimental conditions) in order to obtain larger training datasets for modelling.
The majority of the studies listed in table 1 use the same datasets of nanomaterials (mainly metal oxides, the reason for this is the lack of sufficient data on other nanomaterials for modelling purposes) and therefore the same measured endpoints, the only difference being the type of descriptors employed to develop the (Q)SAR models. These studies, however, reach basically the same mechanistic conclusions and display comparable predictivity.
2.2 Unambiguous algorithm
Almost all studies report the (Q)SAR regression equations or the classification conditions that characterize the tree structures, and accurately describe the statistical methods employed to obtain the regression equations/classification tree,s as well as the methodology deployed to calculate the descriptors. Some exploratory algorithms (e.g., Fourches et al. 2010, Chau and Yap 2012, Liu et al. 2013) used to understand variation in datasets are inherently ambiguous and cannot be recommended for regulatory applications (e.g., the architecture of neural network models does not generally correspond in any obvious way with underlying mechanisms of action, OECD 2007): these regression methods are not transparent and therefore not acceptable for regulatory use.
2.3 Defined domain of applicability
The majority of (Q)SAR studies employ metal oxides as test compounds. Studies that report the applicability domain of the (Q)SAR models are Mu et al 2015, Kar et al. 2014, Jagiello et al. 2016, Gajewicz et al. 2015, Puzyn et al. 2011, and Fourches et al. 2010; the leverage approach is used to determine the model’s applicability domain. In all other (Q)SAR models, the applicability domain should be calculated from published raw data of the (Q)SAR models, where possible.
2.4 Appropriate measures of goodness-of-fit, robustness and predictivity
Almost all (Q)SAR models report appropriate measures of goodness-of-fit, robustness and predictivity; most models, however, do not report the statistical significance of each descriptor in the model. This means that it is not always clear whether each descriptor in a (Q)SAR model is statistically relevant to make the predictions. For example, descriptors with high p-values (e.g. p>0.05) should be disregarded to avoid wrong mechanistic interpretations (a descriptor that has a low p-value is likely to be a meaningful addition to the (Q)SAR model because changes in the descriptor's value are related to changes in the response variable). For example, the (Q)SAR model developed by Mu et al. (see figure 1) employs two descriptors, one of which has a p-value of 0.086 (or 0.095: two different values are reported for the same descriptor). When two descriptors are used in the (Q)SAR model (as in the original publication), the model’s R2 is around 0.90. When only one descriptor is used to develop the model (in this case, the descriptor named enthalpy of
AC C
EP TE
D
M
AN
U
SC R
IP T
formation of a gaseous cation) the R2 is 0.87. In this case the use of one additional descriptor increases the R2 by only 0.03, suggesting that changes in the second descriptor are not associated with changes in the observed response.
Figure 1. Left: model developed with one descriptor (the enthalpy of formation of a gaseous cation, data taken from Mu et al. 2015); right: model developed with 2 descriptors by Mu et al. 2015 (Z/r is the ratio between the cation’s formal charge and its ionic radius).
In some studies, the collinearity between descriptors is set too high with respect to recommended values: for example, in Sizochenko et al. (2014), descriptors are discarded when collinearity, measured by R2, is higher than 0.9 instead of the recommended value of 0.8 (Dearden et al. 2009); if two descriptors in a given (Q)SAR model are highly collinear, they contribute the same information twice, thus confounding the statistical association and making it more difficult to deduce a mechanistic interpretation.
2.5 Mechanistic interpretation
All (Q)SAR models analysed here attempt to propose a mechanism of action in compliance with the selected (relevant) descriptors and their coefficients. This procedure, however, can be hampered by the lack of consideration of all potentially relevant descriptors during the model’s development phase (at this stage, one would like to include as much information as possible to represent the structure of nanomaterials and their interaction with the environment and then use an algorithm to select the best set of descriptors according to their relevance in predicting the measured endpoint). All (Q)SAR studies discussed in this report, in fact, do not employ an exhaustive set of descriptors (or experimentally measured physicochemical properties) able to fully characterize the structure and behaviour of nanomaterials. The majority of these models use toxicity data available from literature studies, and this data concerns mainly metal oxide nanoparticles. For this class of nanomaterials, the most plausible properties responsible for toxicity are solubility (i.e., ion toxicity possibly via a Fenton type of reactivity) and particle’s reactivity (i.e., interference with cellular redox equilibrium and radical formation via catalytic activity).

sections.heading: 3. Information Needed to Apply the (Q)SAR Models
sections.text:
When a (Q)SAR model is available, in order to make a prediction for a new structure which falls within the model’s applicability domain, it is necessary to calculate the descriptors that characterize this new structure. This means that structural information as close as possible to the real nanomaterial must be available.
Depending on the type of descriptors used to develop a (Q)SAR model, information at different levels of detail on the nanomaterials structure is required. In principle, to calculate descriptors based on ab initio methods (e.g. for a TiO2 nanoparticle), information on the location of every atom in the structure should be available (this means information on bulk crystallographic structure, planes exposed to the surface, structural defects, and nanomaterial’s dimensions). From this information, the descriptors can be calculated using a material/molecular modelling software (see figure 2): first the material’s structure is obtained by energy minimization procedures and then this energy minimized structure is used as input for further calculation of descriptors.
Figure 2. Workflow to calculate descriptors from atomic coordinates of nanomaterials (CIF: Crystallographic Information File).
In practice, this process is unlikely to occur for most nanomaterials because (i) often such detailed structural information is lacking (except for a few well studied nanomaterials) and because (ii) a calculation of descriptors based on first principles on the full structure of a nanomaterial would require a lot of computational time. For this reason, modellers use empirical methods, which are less time consuming, or try to focus the calculation of descriptors on the parts of a nanomaterial’s structure which are considered to be involved in the, e.g., nano-bio interactions or toxicity mechanism (i.e., at the molecular initiating event). The calculation of descriptors for carbonaceous nanomaterials is less problematic than that for metal and metal oxide structures, because fullerenes, nanotubes, graphene and the like are based on light atoms. In this case, there are numerous codes and programmes based on classical mechanics principles that use parametrized force fields to calculate the potential energy of a system: from this energy minimized structure the desired descriptors are obtained.
Some (Q)SAR models listed in table 1 that consider metal oxides (Puzyn et al. 2011, Gajewicz et al. 2015, Mu et al. 2016), require material/molecular modelling software such as MOPAC 2009 (Stewart Computational Chemistry, 2009), which uses PM6 semi-empirical methods to energy minimize the structure of nanomaterials and calculate their descriptors. Other (Q)SAR models also developed for metal oxides (Burello and Worth 2011, Zhang et al. 2012, Kaweeteerawat et al. 2015) use descriptors which are derived from empirical equations and experimental data, and therefore do not need the use of dedicated software, but rather standard thermodynamic properties and data from X-ray crystallography (such as ionic radii of elements in the crystals). These empirical models cannot account for a detailed description of the nanomaterials’ structure, but have the advantage of consuming less computational time (and often give more correct descriptor values, as described below). Some (Q)SAR models listed in table 1 employ more than one software package to calculate the descriptors: for example Jagiello et al. use Dragon 6.0 (Talete
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
2014) and Gaussian 09 (Frisch et al. 2009). Some (Q)SAR models do not calculate properties of the nanomaterials but rather descriptors of molecules which constitute the coating of the materials, with the assumption that only the outermost atoms are responsible for the interactions with cell components and other biological structures: for example Fourches et al. (2010) employ the software package developed by Chemical Computing Group (commercial software) to obtain the descriptors that characterize the structure of molecules covering the surface of nanoparticles. Other studies (Toropov et al. 2013, 2014, 2015a, 2015b) employ Quasi-SMILES descriptors, which are arrays of codes that contain some properties and experimental test conditions of nanomaterials (e.g., the concentration of nanoparticles in a test assay). The advantage of using these QuasiSMILES is that they do not require a dedicated software for their calculation; however, these descriptors, although they include important metadata, neglect to consider key structural information of nanomaterials (in Quasi-SMILES, the labelling of nanomaterials by a letter poses a limit to the applicability and predictivity of the models developed using these descriptors).
Once the descriptors have been calculated, one can use them in the model equations or classification schemes to obtain the predicted toxicity outcome. In this case, all studies reviewed here report the detailed (Q)SAR equation with weighting coefficients for each descriptor. Only in the case when neural networks or other non-transparent algorithms are used, the equation to obtain the predicted toxicity values is not reported (e.g., see Fourches et al. 2010). It is also necessary to verify that the nanomaterial, whose toxicity needs to be predicted, falls within the applicability domain of the model; some of the studies here analysed give detailed information on the applicability domain; in other models, it is necessary to verify whether the new untested nanomaterial falls within the applicability domain of the (Q)SAR model. The project nanoBridges (Ambure et al. 2015) is currently developing a computational platform to perform (Q)SAR modelling on nanomaterials, where all steps of (Q)SAR model development are automated. The platform includes, among others, computational tools for variable selection, clustering of data, and calculation of applicability domains and descriptors for some classes of nanomaterials.
Very often, authors do not report on the correlation between calculated descriptors and experimental measured properties. Some published studies and project reports (e.g. nanoBridges and nanoPUZZLES, Puzyn et al. 2011, Gajewicz et al. 2015, Mu et al. 2015) calculate descriptors using PM6 methods; however, when comparing the experimentally measured data with the calculated descriptors, the PM6 method does not yield the correct values. For example, the band gap of TiO2, which experimentally is around 3 and 3.2 eV for bulk rutile and anatase, respectively (Diebold 2003), is reported to be 7.47 eV when calculated with PM6 methods (see figure 3). Similarly, studies that report the calculations on the size dependency of electronic properties obtained with PM6 methods are not in line with the experimental evidence. In these cases, it is suggested that, besides the need to compare calculations with measured values, there should be an effort to verify if some codes like, for example, VASP (a computer program for atomic scale materials modelling from first principles, Kresse 2010), are capable of delivering descriptor values which are comparable to the experimental measurement.
Although the requirement to verify whether a descriptor is capable of reproducing its corresponding experimental measurement is not included in the five OECD principles for (Q)SAR validation, it is important that descriptors reflect the measured physicochemical characteristics of the nanomaterials. Indeed, the fact whether a descriptor is capable of reproducing an experimental value has profound consequences on the construction and validity of a (Q)SAR model. If a calculated descriptor does not correlate with the corresponding experimental property, the procedure to search for the best correlation among a set of descriptors and a measured endpoint will necessarily be affected: i.e., although such property could be correlated to the measured endpoint, the (Q)SAR model will never include it as a relevant descriptor. Moreover, if a descriptor is correlated with the measured endpoint, but not correlated with the experimental property, the (Q)SAR model will result in a false mechanism of action. Since nanomaterials display a structural
AC C
EP
TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
variability that depends on their synthesis and history (i.e., interaction with the environment), it is essential to capture the correct information regarding their actual structure and properties. For example, several key characteristics of nanomaterials are very sensitive to environmental conditions and the presence of contaminants: the wettability can increase due to surface contamination by atmospheric hydrocarbons, the surface charge can vary depending on the presence of different elements on the surface, and solubility can change due to doping of the original compound. Therefore, descriptors should be developed and tailored using material’s specific information provided by the physicochemical characterization (e.g., from XPS), rather than using idealized structures. This issue should be also considered when different exposure methods are employed to study the toxicological effects in test assays. For example, exposure of nanomaterial samples via aerosol and instillation can lead to different endpoint outcomes. This happens not only because the deposited dose and dose rate can be different, but also because the nanomaterials can interact with different contaminants during exposure. In aerosol exposures, the nanomaterials can adsorb contaminants present in the air, while in instillation, different chemicals present in solution can adsorb on the surface of nanomaterials. Therefore, while the same nanomaterial is tested, different type of chemicals present on its surface can change its surface characteristics eventually affecting fate and toxicity.
Figure 3. Band gap values of metal oxides calculated using the PM6 method (Puzyn et al. 2011) compared with: (left) bandgap of oxide materials calculated from their experimental enthalpy of formation (Burello and Worth 2011, data taken from Hanbook of Chemistry and Physics 2006); (right) bandgap of nanoparticles measured by Zhang et al. (2012).

sections.heading: 4. Datasets Used for the Development of (Q)SAR Models
sections.text:
Datasets which are useful for (Q)SAR modelling should contain a sufficient number of diverse sampled nanomaterials: these two conditions (diversity and sufficiently high number of samples) are currently hard to come by, except when high-throughput screening (HTS) methods are used (e.g., Zhang et al. 2012, Fourches et al. 2010, Kaweeteerawat et al. 2015). These three studies provide enough data for (Q)SAR modelling and read-across. In principle, one could collect information from different experimental studies to obtain larger groups of sampled nanomaterials; however, this is possible only if the test conditions are the same across different studies. Currently the standardization of test conditions for nanomaterials is still under development, so large datasets are still rare.
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
Recently, efforts from EU projects such as eNANOMAPPER and nanoPUZZLES have been focussing on data curation, collection and ontology definition for the development of databases that store information on the physicochemical characteristics (both intrinsic and extrinsic properties) and endpoint measurements of nanomaterials. Some of this information is publicly available, but other sources have still restricted access; the aim of these projects is to create large databases of nanomaterials which contain curated information that will allow read-across and (Q)SAR modelling. In this way, by looking at larger datasets, the (Q)SAR models developed in the future will be more robust.

sections.heading: 5. Mechanisms of Toxicity
sections.text:
The majority of the published (Q)SAR studies is currently focusing on the same datasets and therefore the same in vitro endpoints, namely metal oxides and oxidative stress (Burello and Worth 2011, Zhang et al. 2012, Gajewicz et al. 2015, Mu et al. 2015). In these studies, bioreactivity and ROS generation are the dominant mechanisms of action that emerge from the (Q)SAR models (see figure 4 and Auffan et al. 2009, Burello and Worth 2011). For these nanomaterial classes, redox potentials, energy band levels and dissolution emerge as the most relevant properties to account for bioreactivity, ROS generation, oxidative stress and finally inflammation. In this context, it seems that particle reactivity (of metal oxides) can be predicted using the conduction band energy level (Ec), whereas dissolution (of metal oxides) can be represented by the formal charge of the cation (Z)1 or by the enthalpy of formation of a gaseous cation (Puzyn et al. 2011). The importance of the energy band structure of nanomaterials in determining nanotoxicity has also been highlighted in a recent final report from the CEFIC LRI N4 project (Bouwmeester et al. 2016), where the authors suggest to include the LUMO energy (i.e. the energy of the Lowest Unoccupied Molecular Orbital, which is roughly equivalent to the Ec energy level) as a screening criterion into the DF4nanoGrouping scheme (Arts et al. 2015). As there is now some evidence and consensus among different studies that the Ec descriptor can be correlated with in vitro and in vivo toxicity of nanomaterials (Zhang, et al. 2012, Kaweeteerawat et al. 2015, Sisler et al. 2016, Burello 2017), this property is already in use in some risk assessment schemes to classify and rank the toxic potency of nanomaterials (see for example the precautionary matrix developed in Höck et al. 2013 and in Groso et al. 2016). In addition, since other (nano)materials such as quantum dots or perovskites are semiconductors, it is expected that also for this class of nanomaterials the Ec descriptor, and the valence band energy level, could be potentially useful in describing bioreactivity and functionality.
The study from Fourches et al. (2010) analyses surface properties of nanoparticles that affect cellular uptake, as an important contributor to the overall toxicity. In this study, the nanomaterials are metal oxide nanoparticles with the same core material but different surface coatings; the relevant descriptors playing a role in the uptake process are related to the hydrophobicity of the coating materials. Other studies employing the same dataset of Fourches et al. (2010) but different descriptors and model algorithms (see table 1) reach analogous conclusions. Another study (Cho et al. 2012) posits the mechanism of lysosomal destabilization by nano-metal oxides as a driver leading to inflammation in vivo; in this case the properties responsible for this effect are the particle’s zeta potential and the dissolution to toxic ions.
Overall, there is quite reliable evidence to support the relevance of the above mentioned properties on the mechanism of toxicity of nanomaterials: however, due to the difficulty of calculating and/or
1 As a rule of thumb, the dissolution of bulk oxide materials increases as the formal charge (Z) of their cation decreases: oxides with formal charge Z=+1 are usually reactive or very soluble in water (e.g. Ag2O and Na2O), those having Z=+2 are soluble in slightly acidic conditions (e.g. CuO and ZnO), oxides with Z=+3 are usually soluble in acidic conditions, whereas for Z=+4 the oxides are defined as insoluble (qualitative data taken from Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 2006).
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
obtaining descriptors/properties for nanomaterials, many of the (Q)SAR models available to date were developed without taking into account all potentially relevant characteristics (e.g. electronic, steric, charge, etc.) which can comprehensively describe the structure and behaviour of nanomaterials. In this case, researchers could use experimentally derived physicochemical properties, when the calculation of descriptors is not computationally feasible, to capture other potentially relevant molecular initiating events. In addition, the chemical space sampled by toxicological tests is still too small to reach general conclusions on the nanomaterials’ modes of action of, and this is due to the lack of a sufficient number of tested nanomaterials and/or availability of reliable data.
One promising approach to correlate modes of action of nanomaterials with their physicochemical characteristics is that of combining OMICs techniques (such as proteomics and genomics) with (Q)SAR modelling and bioinformatics tools. It is expected that these in silico techniques can play a key role in understanding and modelling the large amount of data that are likely to be delivered in the OMICs area.
AC C

Figure 4. Top: Plot of the Redox Potential value (Eh) of various biologically active redox couples (BARC) compared to the Eh characteristics of metallic nanoparticles. This figure shows the correlation between the ability of metallic nanoparticles to generate a potential toxicity when they can be oxidized, reduced or dissolved in biological in vitro conditions (fully or partially oxidized nanoparticles have an Eh higher than the Eh of biologically active redox couples; fully or partially reduced nanoparticles are characterized by an Eh lower than the Eh of biologically active redox couples, Auffan et al. 2009). Middle: Plot of Eh value of various BARC compared to the calculated conduction and valence band energy levels of an oxide nanoparticle. This figure shows the proposed mechanism of ROS generation by oxide nanomaterials involving electron transfer from BARC (reduction of nanoparticles occurs when Ec is comprised within the redox potentials of biologically active redox couples, Burello and Worth 2011). Bottom: Toxicological impact of metal dissolution and conduction band energy of metal oxide nanoparticles. Cytotoxic potential of nanoparticles was defined by the area under normalized dose-response curve in LDH assay (Zhang et al. 2012).

sections.heading: 6. Role of (Q)SAR Models in Tiered Testing, Grouping, Functional Assays and Assessment Schemes
sections.text:
Some of the most investigated properties involved in the mechanisms of toxicity of nanomaterials, such as reactivity/ROS generation and dissolution seem promising as a first screening tool; however, their implementation requires more insight to confirm the relevance of these properties and how they could be used in a test system. The study of Zhang et al. (2012) gives a practical proof of concept on how a (Q)SAR model can be used to screen nanomaterials before in vitro and in vivo testing. In this study, the authors also show that if some kind of knowledge regarding the mechanism of action of nanomaterials is available, in this specific case the possibility of metal oxide nanoparticles to interfere with the cellular redox species, then acellular tests can be developed to identify nanomaterials that can generate oxidative stress. Specifically, the authors showed by spectroscopic analysis and using the redox couple cytochrome c-Fe3+/cytochrome cFe2+ as chemical probe, the capability of metal oxide nanoparticles to oxidise the reduced form of cytochrome.
The (Q)SAR methodologies developed so far will certainly help to group nanomaterials and perform read-across for regulatory purposes. The diversity of the nanomaterials tested, however, is still low and therefore the applicability of these concepts is restricted to a few materials. For example, there is no clear answer when one tries to apply the grouping concepts developed for simple metal oxides to more complex structures such as coated, core@shell or mixed oxides. In this context, it is also necessary to take into account the structural diversity of sampled nanomaterials according to both extrinsic and intrinsic properties. For example, silica particles could differ by the density of surface hydroxyl groups, a feature which can be determined by XPS methods and can affect surface charge, wettability and reactivity.
(Q)SAR models can be used also to analyze the results of functional assays (FAs) to provide empirical relationships between the calculated physicochemical parameters that describe the structure of nanomaterials and the endpoint(s) measured in the FAs. Functional assays have all the complexity of a test system and (Q)SAR methods can be helpful in identifying which combination of nanomaterial properties matter most in determining the activity measured during the functional assays. Examples of such FAs could cover the determination of nanomaterial’s reactivity, agglomeration or interaction with proteins, DNA, cell membrane and other cellular components. These experiments would be ideally conducted using HTS equipment.
The (Q)SAR methodologies could be also useful for ranking the toxic potency of the nanomaterials in risk assessment schemes. Currently, an example where a validated (Q)SAR model is used in a risk assessment scheme is the Swiss Precautionary Matrix developed by TEMAS in Switzerland (Höck et al. 2013) for the Swiss Federal Council (FOEN). Other frameworks that could accommodate the (Q)SAR models are control banding tools such as the CB Nanotool developed at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in the United States (Paik et al. 2008). Eventually, when validated (Q)S R models will be also available for ecotoxicity, these predictive models could be coupled with dynamic flows of nanomaterials to several environmental and technical compartments (Sun et al. 2017).

sections.heading: 7. Knowledge Gaps
sections.text:
One of the most significant knowledge gaps that hampers the development of (Q)SAR models for nanomaterials is the lack of computational methodologies for the calculation of descriptors that can represent both extrinsic and intrinsic physicochemical properties. The solutions adopted for modelling could be diverse, mirroring the structural and behavioural heterogeneity of nanomaterials. Due to the size and structural complexity of nanomaterials and the presence of heavy atoms, it is difficult to obtain at the moment a realistic description of a nanomaterial surface
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
structure which is supposed to play a role in toxicity and fate mechanisms. Properties like (surface) electronic states and wettability are certainly important: their calculation can be easier for carbonaceous nanomaterials such as nanotubes, but for clusters containing heavy atoms, empirical methodologies like QSPRs (Quantitative Structure-Property Relationships) could be a solution for obtaining extrinsic properties of nanomaterials as well as to predict the outcome of functional assays (e.g. for the development of QSPR models to predict the PZC (point of zero charge) of metal oxides see Burello 2015). Also, reliable experimental data on properties like wettability, which is expected to play a significant role in nano-bio interactions and fate, is currently lacking.
Another major knowledge gap is the lack of curated datasets that can be readily used to develop the models. In this sense, there is a need for data obtained from standardized testing protocols and complemented with metadata. In addition, the ongoing development of reporting formats and ontologies is highly required to enable interoperability. Repositories with well-characterized nanomaterials will help to get reliable and comparable results.
Another important topic concerns the modelling of the nano-bio interactions, which includes all the interactions of nanomaterials with different components of a cell (e.g., proteins, receptors, membrane, DNA, etc.). It would be very beneficial to explore these interactions for example by developing functional assays which can then be modelled by QSPR methods. To this end, it is essential that modellers and experimentalists work in close collaboration at the design of experiments.

sections.heading: 8. Recommendations
9. Conclusions
sections.text:
Overall, given that the majority of the (Q)SAR models here analysed do not fully comply with all the five OECD validation principles and/or do not consider relevant endpoints, the use of these models for regulatory purposes can be proposed, at the moment, only in a weight of evidence approach and therefore in conjunction with other in vitro and in vivo information. To improve this condition, (Q)SAR modellers need good datasets to develop their models. These datasets should be ideally collected from experiments performed under standardized conditions and should contain metadata as well. One crucial knowledge gap is the lack of nano-specific descriptors (e.g., description accounting for surface properties): currently, this information is difficult to obtain due to the size, structural complexity and lack of experimental measurements of nanomaterials. Initially, one
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
solution could be the use of measured physicochemical properties (obtained from standardized protocols to ensure accuracy and reproducibility of measurements) in the (Q)SAR models: the use of experimental properties has its advantages, however, this approach does not allow the full potential of (Q)SAR modelling to be exploited, which lies in its predictivity towards virtual compounds. In the future, the use of QSPR methods to predict both extrinsic properties of nanomaterials and the results of functional assays seems a reasonable way to go.
So far, electronic energy levels and dissolution are the most used relevant properties to describe nanotoxicity, but it is likely that other material characteristics like wettability will play a relevant role not only in toxicity but also in determining fate.
Computational methodologies are an essential tool, because ultimately we want to use in silico approaches to complement and substitute the experiments. The (Q)SAR techniques can be applied for read-across, for analyzing the outcome of functional assays (e.g. with or without cells and possibly in high-throughput screening methods), for outlining Adverse Outcome Pathways and Modes of Action and for supporting the design of safe nanomaterials during the R&D phase (i.e., by combining information on functionality and safety/toxicity). In order to become fully operational in these areas, the (Q)SAR methodology requires more theoretical insights and stronger collaborations between experimentalists and modelers to yield useful datasets.
Funding. This research was funded by the EU H2020 project ProSafe (Promoting the Implementation of Safe by Design), under grant agreement 646325.
Acknowledgements. The author wants to thank the ProSafe’s project coordinators Phil Sayre and Klaus Guenter Steinhaeuser for their contribution in reviewing the manuscript and Aart Dijkzeul, James Baker and others at the ProSafe’s project office for their continuous support.

referenceMentions.context: A comprehensive assessment of the toxicological effects of nanomaterials is necessary for meeting regulatory requirements and for the design of products that are safe and operate as intended (Burello 2015).

EPA 2015), such as solid-water partition coefficients, stickiness coefficients, and rate constants for dissolution, cannot be discounted and may help to develop reliable environmental fate models (Westerhoff and Nowack 2013).
While only one study focusses on in vivo endpoints (Burello 2017), the rest of the literature concentrates on in vitro effects.

The importance of the energy band structure of nanomaterials in determining nanotoxicity has also been highlighted in a recent final report from the CEFIC LRI N4 project (Bouwmeester et al. 2016), where the authors suggest to include the LUMO energy (i.

metadata.abstractText: A comprehensive understanding of the relationships between the physicochemical properties and the behavior of nanomaterials in biological systems is required for designing safe and functional nanomaterials. Quantitative Structure-Activity Relationship (QSAR) methods help to establish such relationships, and their growing importance for providing key information is reflected in a number of regulatory frameworks (e.g., Registration Evaluation Authorization and Restriction of Chemical Substances (REACH)), where these approaches are considered acceptable, under certain conditions, for filling in knowledge gaps for untested chemicals. The (Q)SAR methodology is well known and extensively applied in the areas of drug discovery and chemical toxicity modeling for guiding the experimental design of chemical compounds, but its application to nanomaterials still requires major advancements. This review analyses the currently available (Q)S R models for regulatory assessment of nanomaterials risks. The survey first analyzes and discusses the regulatory relevance and reliability of models within the context of the 5 OECD (Q)SAR validation criteria. Then, the information required to apply the models is outlined, focusing especially on descriptor development. The most important mechanisms of toxicity, knowledge gaps that impede the development of structure-activity models, as well as the domains where (Q)SAR models are expected to convey fundamental contributions, such as in tiered testing schemes and analysis of functional assays’ results, are also discussed. It is concluded that the development of (Q)SAR models for nanomaterials requires both the development of nanospecific descriptors and curated experimental datasets. ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
